A lot of people are complaining about 360 degree camera and nicer infotainment, but only a fewer people know thats where Tata is earning money. 360 camera and better infotainment requires more semiconductor sensor chips and there has been a global shortage of it. Thats why XUV700 has waiting period of 15 months, where as Safari is available within 45 days. People who don‚Äôt wanna wait for 18 months are going for Safari and that‚Äôs where Tata is earning money. Thats called business.

I have booked safari dark over over Xuv 700:
1) Superb road presence.  Can compete with fortuner,  though it is a segment above.
2) Interior feels plush (except for poor infotainment system) due to soft touch materials used.
3) Get a 7 seater. Because safari is proper 7 seater or atleast you can use it as 6 seater by tumbling one side of the last row seat to increase the boot capacity. 

Do not buy 6 seater in safari or other cars, because in this segment, the last row is not so wide like fortuner or endeavors. And ultimately, you will be forced to use this 6 seater as 4 seater car due to compromised last row. 

This is unacceptable, if you fathom that triber or ertiga is good 7 seater than these cars are.

In case of Hector or alacazar, it is a 4 seater (if you are going for 6 seater configuration), because last row is barely usable. 
4) All features except for adas, are present in safari too. Bad impression comes due to infotainment systems.
5) JBL is very good over Sony speakers. It may seem weird, but park xuv700 and safari and play same song, you'll understand what I am saying. Somehow the bass and treble is better in JBL. Sony was just being loud than JBL. Quality was compromised.

Most reviewers failed to educate masses about drivetrain configuration or layout ....
Previous safari was a body on frame chasis vehicle with a longitudinally mounted engine ( rear wheel drive paltform ) with 4 wheel drive integration .... I am assuming the previous safari has low range gear ratios as well as locking differentials ...
But the new safari is a monocoque -  (car like) chassis with a frint wheel drive based layout where engine is mounted transversely or sideways with all wheel drive integration.... So it's basically an front wheel biased druve train whwre engine senrs mote power to front wheels .... Its nit a typical 4*4 odf road worthy ...
Plus i know harrier has an inferior torsion beam rear suspension thats a big - a huge let down..new safari too had the same i guess....

Hi there, I watched your videos on YouTube and think you might be able to help me with some questions. I‚Äôm considering the Safari, XUV700, and Scorpio N for my needs. I have a large family of seven, and I plan to travel across India‚Äînot to extreme locations like deserts, but to places like Ladakh, Spiti, and Manali where there might be snow and black ice.

I‚Äôm wondering if the Safari will be suitable for these conditions or if I should opt for the XUV700 with all-wheel drive or the Scorpio N with 4x4. I‚Äôm leaning towards the Safari due to its impressive road presence and comfort, but the XUV700 is appealing for its performance. However, I‚Äôm also concerned about the reliability of Tata cars. Do you think the Safari is reliable? If you were choosing a new car, would you go for the Safari or a Mahindra model?

Tata, the absence of physical buttons is a deal-breaker for me. While I was excited about considering the Harrier or a Safari, I prioritize safety and convenience. Despite Tata's excellent crash ratings, I have 15 years of driving experience in basic cars like the 800 and Alto, which lacked safety features. This has made me a cautious driver. For the past five years, I've enjoyed the security of advanced safety features, so fumbling with non-physical controls and diverting my attention from the road doesn't make sense. I'll have to pass on these vehicles.
